review: Google Chromecast is a slick little inexpensive device that works very well at streaming media to a TV or HDMI monitor, but it only works with apps that were designed to support it (like Chrome, Netflix and YouTube). At the current time, this is rather limited, so you can't stream music, pictures or videos stored on your phone or tablet. I expect this will improve with time as more developers add support for it.

author: aris

review: There are times where you are sitting in your living room and a particular YouTube video, or website comes up.  You want to show it off, and everyone huddles around your phone to see.  Enter Chromecast.I'm using a 6 year old sony XBR (non-smart) tv with the chromecast.  Video signal is transmitted over an HDMI port, and the Chromecast is powered using the USB connection on the TV.  Setup is quick and painless  utilizing an app available for download online via browser for your computer, or in either respective store for iOS or Android.  Right now, you can "cast" any content from a browser window directly to your TV, in addition to specific support for Netflix and HULU (soon to come I believe).  I hear there is further development going on to implement more features (i.e. casting local filesystem content).If you don't have a smart TV, game console, or any other way to view streaming video content at your TV, this is an indispensable device.  Even if you do have those things, at $35 this is a nice toy to play with, providing a backup in case your other video streaming hardware options bite the dust (my XBOX 360 just died recently).  You can literally move a streaming video mid-view to your tv, and continue to control the playback via phone or tablet.
